    Important :
    What is the accelerated study plan?
    I
    Mission Tasks
    I'm Short on Study Time!

    If you are short on time and have already scored a 79 or higher on quant on either an official GMAT practice test from www.mba.com or an actual GMAT exam, AND if you are within 3 points of your target GMAT quant score, you can consider using the accelerated study plan.

    Here is how the accelerated study plan works:

    Instead of following the complete study plan, which has you first read a course chapter and then complete all chapter tests for that chapter, you begin the accelerated study plan by taking chapter tests, starting with the Essential GMAT Quant Skills chapter.

    After completing each test, spend time carefully reviewing your wrong answers. While reviewing your wrong answers, you will notice that each question has one or more “lesson” tags associated with it. Using those tags, you can click back to the associated lesson to read more about a certain topic. For instance, let’s say you get a difference of squares question wrong; below the solution, you will find a difference of squares tag that when clicked will bring you back to the chapter lesson on difference of squares. In that lesson, you can read more about difference of squares, do example problems, and watch video solutions on that topic.

    Follow this review process for any chapter test questions you answer incorrectly or don’t understand. This method will ensure that while you’re saving time by forgoing the full course readings, you’re using the chapter text strategically to target those areas where you have gaps in knowledge or need further practice to boost your score.

    Now - as you see from the study plan, we define minimum accuracy level for the easy, medium, and hard tests. If you hit the recommended accuracy goals within a particular test, you should then take another test of similar difficulty or the next level of difficulty. We recommend that you take a minimum of 4 tests for each chapter.

    If you score under the accuracy goal on a test, then we advise that you read the entire chapter associated with that test. Thus, for chapters you know well, following the standard accelerated study plan should work well; however, if the data are showing that you do not have a high proficiency in a chapter, be sure to spend time reading the chapter, and then follow your reading by taking chapter tests. Remember, the accelerated study plan is a framework to save time if you are already at a certain level of readiness for the GMAT, but you may need to adjust your approach to the plan based on how you perform on the tests.

    Once you have taken a few tests from a particular chapter, go to OnTarget to further determine your exact weaknesses in that chapter. From OnTarget, you can read more about a particular topic, complete further practice questions on that topic, or review past incorrect answers.
    Next

    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    Read this first
    S
    Mission Tasks

    If you follow this study plan, there is no limit to how high you can score on the GMAT, but you must complete this study plan exactly as it's presented to you, step-by-step.

    This course is broken into two major phases. In the first phase - the knowledge, content, and skills development phase - you master the content, knowledge and skills necessary to earn an impressive GMAT score. After completing this course, you'll be substantially more prepared than your competition.

    In the second phase - the practice-test phase - you'll take and review six official GMAT practice tests. In this phase, you'll perfect all of the new knowledge and skills you developed, under realistic test conditions.

    The course is broken into missions. Because this course was designed for the serious GMAT student, we strongly recommend that you complete all of the missions in the order in which they are presented. Doing so will help give you the most thorough understanding of the material presented.

    Additionally, the accelerated study plan at the top of this page features additional ways to use the course, but it is recommended only if you are short on time and meet the following criteria: You have already scored a 79 or higher on Quant on either an Official GMAT practice test from www.mba.com or an actual GMAT exam, and you are within 3 points of your target Quant score. Otherwise, let's get started!

    Please perform the following steps:

    Download and Print the Target Test Prep GMAT Quant Equation Guide

    Completed In Progress Not Completed Incomplete

    Although the GMAT is a reasoning test, knowing key formulas and concepts will make that reasoning much easier. Download and print the Target Test Prep GMAT Quant Equation Guide. Keep this guide handy as you progress through the chapters. In addition, begin putting these key formulas and concepts on flash card. Then regularly review your flashcards. Your goal is to have these tools available to you from memory.

    Next

    Familiarize Yourself with the Target Test Prep Must Know Page

    Completed In Progress Not Completed Incomplete

    Each chapter has dozens of tips, tricks, important formulas, critical concepts, and time-saving techniques. In each chapter, we bring your attention to the most important of these tools in call-outs, which we refer to as "Must Knows".

    Although you will encounter all of these Must Knows as you progress through the course, in each chapter, for your convenience we have provided them in one central location.

    Please familiarize yourself with this page. Then, please begin putting each of these Must Knows on a flash card. Begin to review these flash cards regularly.

    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier.     How to Practice with the GMAT™ Official Guide
    The GMAT™ Official Guide questions have been added to the missions as optional extra practice. Some students find them helpful for reinforcing skills, while others prefer to stick to the TTP study plan alone. They’re not required to complete the course—you can treat them as bonus material if you feel you’d benefit from the extra reps.

    If you’re interested in accessing them, you can purchase the GMAT™ Official Guide 2025–2026 here
    REMEMBER
    • When practicing these questions, you do not have to use a timer as we want you to focus on accuracy more than timing. Timing will come as you become more accurate.
    • Many of these questions relate to lessons you have read in the previous chapter, but some may be on the outskirts of what you have learned and that is OK! In TTP, we are not teaching you to just do well with OG questions but rather to develop a skillset that allows you to crush anything that comes your day on test day.
    • If you get something wrong, sometimes reading the solution will be sufficient enough to find and fix any knowledge gaps.
    • Lastly, although we have assigned these questions, we are unable to provide our own solutions due to copyright reasons. If you have any questions about this, feel free to reach out.

    GMAT® is a registered trademark of the Graduate Management Admission Council™. The Graduate Management Admission Council does not endorse nor is it affiliated in any way with Target Test Prep or any content of this website.

    • Inequalities and Absolute Values
    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    How to Practice with the GMAT™ Official Guide
    The GMAT™ Official Guide questions have been added to the missions as optional extra practice. Some students find them helpful for reinforcing skills, while others prefer to stick to the TTP study plan alone. They’re not required to complete the course—you can treat them as bonus material if you feel you’d benefit from the extra reps.

    If you’re interested in accessing them, you can purchase the GMAT™ Official Guide 2025–2026 here
    REMEMBER
    • When practicing these questions, you do not have to use a timer as we want you to focus on accuracy more than timing. Timing will come as you become more accurate.
    • Many of these questions relate to lessons you have read in the previous chapter, but some may be on the outskirts of what you have learned and that is OK! In TTP, we are not teaching you to just do well with OG questions but rather to develop a skillset that allows you to crush anything that comes your day on test day.
    • If you get something wrong, sometimes reading the solution will be sufficient enough to find and fix any knowledge gaps.
    • Lastly, although we have assigned these questions, we are unable to provide our own solutions due to copyright reasons. If you have any questions about this, feel free to reach out.

    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    How to Practice with the GMAT™ Official Guide
    The GMAT™ Official Guide questions have been added to the missions as optional extra practice. Some students find them helpful for reinforcing skills, while others prefer to stick to the TTP study plan alone. They’re not required to complete the course—you can treat them as bonus material if you feel you’d benefit from the extra reps.

    If you’re interested in accessing them, you can purchase the GMAT™ Official Guide 2025–2026 here
    REMEMBER
    • When practicing these questions, you do not have to use a timer as we want you to focus on accuracy more than timing. Timing will come as you become more accurate.
    • Many of these questions relate to lessons you have read in the previous chapter, but some may be on the outskirts of what you have learned and that is OK! In TTP, we are not teaching you to just do well with OG questions but rather to develop a skillset that allows you to crush anything that comes your day on test day.
    • If you get something wrong, sometimes reading the solution will be sufficient enough to find and fix any knowledge gaps.
    • Lastly, although we have assigned these questions, we are unable to provide our own solutions due to copyright reasons. If you have any questions about this, feel free to reach out.

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    How to Practice with the GMAT™ Official Guide
    The GMAT™ Official Guide questions have been added to the missions as optional extra practice. Some students find them helpful for reinforcing skills, while others prefer to stick to the TTP study plan alone. They’re not required to complete the course—you can treat them as bonus material if you feel you’d benefit from the extra reps.

    If you’re interested in accessing them, you can purchase the GMAT™ Official Guide 2025–2026 here
    REMEMBER
    • When practicing these questions, you do not have to use a timer as we want you to focus on accuracy more than timing. Timing will come as you become more accurate.
    • Many of these questions relate to lessons you have read in the previous chapter, but some may be on the outskirts of what you have learned and that is OK! In TTP, we are not teaching you to just do well with OG questions but rather to develop a skillset that allows you to crush anything that comes your day on test day.
    • If you get something wrong, sometimes reading the solution will be sufficient enough to find and fix any knowledge gaps.
    • Lastly, although we have assigned these questions, we are unable to provide our own solutions due to copyright reasons. If you have any questions about this, feel free to reach out.

    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    How to Practice with the GMAT™ Official Guide
    The GMAT™ Official Guide questions have been added to the missions as optional extra practice. Some students find them helpful for reinforcing skills, while others prefer to stick to the TTP study plan alone. They’re not required to complete the course—you can treat them as bonus material if you feel you’d benefit from the extra reps.

    If you’re interested in accessing them, you can purchase the GMAT™ Official Guide 2025–2026 here
    REMEMBER
    • When practicing these questions, you do not have to use a timer as we want you to focus on accuracy more than timing. Timing will come as you become more accurate.
    • Many of these questions relate to lessons you have read in the previous chapter, but some may be on the outskirts of what you have learned and that is OK! In TTP, we are not teaching you to just do well with OG questions but rather to develop a skillset that allows you to crush anything that comes your day on test day.
    • If you get something wrong, sometimes reading the solution will be sufficient enough to find and fix any knowledge gaps.
    • Lastly, although we have assigned these questions, we are unable to provide our own solutions due to copyright reasons. If you have any questions about this, feel free to reach out.

    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    Practice Test Phase

    Recommended Mission
    Start here :
    Read this first
    S
    Mission Tasks
    Congratulations! You’ve successfully arrived at the practice test phase of your study plan. Since you have completed the learning phase of the course, you are ready to put all of your newfound skills into practice by taking official practice tests from GMAC. This practice test phase is an essential part of your earning a high GMAT score.

    If you want to maximize your GMAT score, this phase will take you four to six weeks. Since there are six official practice tests available, a realistic pace would be to take—and review—one test per week. Of course, if you took one of these tests at the beginning of your GMAT preparation, as many people do, you may have five left.

    The main goals of this practice test phase are to gain familiarity with the GMAT experience, to develop test-taking skills, such as managing your time and focusing under pressure, and to generate results that you can use as a basis for finding weaker areas to strengthen.

    After you complete each practice test, we’ll have you strategically use the TTP course. By leveraging the categorized lessons and problems sets in Target Test Prep, you can efficiently and thoroughly strengthen the weaker areas that you discover by analyzing your practice exams. By using this method to find and strengthen weaker areas, you can fill in gaps in your knowledge and skills to make sure that you are ready to take the actual GMAT and hit your score goal.

    Once you complete this process, you should be well positioned to dominate GMAT quant on test day.

    Before you get started with the practice test phase, be sure to do the following:
    Next

    Purchase all six MBA.com official practice exams

    Completed In Progress Not Completed Incomplete
    You will be using only official GMAT practice tests from GMAC. There are six official practice tests available: two are available for free, and four more must be purchased.
    Next

    Purchase the GMAT test-day "wet-erase" booklet and pen (Give Amazon a try)

    Completed In Progress Not Completed Incomplete
    If you plan to take the in-person GMAT, purchase the GMAT test-day "wet-erase" booklet and pen (Give Amazon a try). If you plan to take the online GMAT, purchase a whiteboard and dry erase marker. Keep in mind that using either the wet erase booklet or a whiteboard will take some time to get used to; using either of those is not as easy as using a nice, comfortable pen and some paper. Thus, you need to begin practicing with either the wet-erase booklet or a whiteboard now and, of course, be sure to use either of them when taking your practice exams.
    Next

    Reread the Strategy Chapter

    Completed In Progress Not Completed Incomplete
    Reread the lesson in the strategy chapter on how to take a full length practice test.

    20.11. Leveraging GMAT Policies to Earn a Higher Score
    Read Lessons
    Coordinate Geometry is Currently Tested on the GMAT
    Updated on: Jul 2025

    While most geometrical concepts were removed from the GMAT Focus Edition, which GMAC now refers to simply as "the GMAT" once again, Coordinate Geometry is still tested.

    In addition, some basic geometry concepts, including calculating the area and perimeter of shapes like squares, triangles, and circles, are still tested on the current GMAT. However, whenever a geometry formula outside of coordinate geometry is required, it will be provided in the question stem.

    Must I take the Business Writing Assessment?
    The BWA is an optional writing test GMAC has created for business schools that prefer to see a standardized writing sample, since the GMAT no longer includes an Analytical Writing section.
    • If you've taken the GRE or the GMAT 10th Edition and have a valid Analytical Writing Assessment (AWA) score from either of those exams, you likely do not need to take the BWA. However, if you took or are planning to take the current GMAT (Focus Edition), which does not include a writing section, some schools may require or recommend that you also sit for the BWA.
    • Harvard Business School (HBS) and MIT Sloan are 2 top schools where applicants who submit a GMAT Focus Edition score or receive a test waiver may be asked to submit a BWA score, either during the interview process or earlier. Applicants who have a GMAT 10th Edition or GRE score with a valid AWA score will already satisfy the writing requirement.
    • If you're unsure whether you need to take the BWA, it's a good idea to contact your target schools directly for clarification.

    Your TTP GMAT Course is updated for the GMAT Focus Edition
    Your entire TTP study experience — every chapter, lesson, and task — has been updated to match the structure, content, and priorities of the new GMAT Focus Edition.
    What these changes mean:
    • You’ll study only and exactly what is tested on the GMAT Focus Edition.
    • Legacy content such as the AWA has been fully removed.
    • All chapters and tasks follow the new section breakdown and content weighting.
    • Coordinate Geometry is still tested on the GMAT Focus and still included in your TTP Quant course.
    • A new Business Writing Assessment (BWA) module has been added to your course. The BWA is an optional writing test that some B-schools may ask for, since the GMAT Focus does not include a writing section.

    You can feel confident that your TTP study plan is completely optimized for the new GMAT exam!

    About Hard Tests

    The questions in this Hard Chapter Test are as difficult as any that appear on the GMAT. So, at this stage of your preparation, it does not make sense to seek answer them in under two minutes.

    Rather, for best results, you should hide the timer and answer these questions untimed, taking as much time as you need to fully understand and analyze each question.

    By practicing in this way, you will give yourself time to learn to see what’s going on in the questions and to learn to work your way to correct answers to difficult questions.
